awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Loading on Coastal Bridges in Windstorms Using Rapidly Deployable Sensor Network
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant seeks to transform coastal bridge resilience through cyberinfrastructure supported extreme event observations.  The damaging effects of severe windstorms including hurricanes on infrastructure of coastal bridges highlight the need for new tools to provide fundamental knowledge of windstorm impacts on infrastructure.  This award supports fundamental research to establish a rapidly deployable, bridge-located observation network to lay the groundwork for capturing measurements of wind, surge, wave, and scour and analysis of bridge responses during a severe storm such as a hurricane.  These efforts will enhance coastal bridge health management decisions as well as design and reliability models through the analysis of hurricane load and response data.  A full-scale prototype of this system deployed on a bridge with interactive system will provide students at all academic levels the opportunity to interact with an in-service bridge and visualize the impacts of bridge management decisions.
  
The rapidly deployable bridge-hurricane observation network will advance fundamental knowledge of the loadings and responses of bridges in coastal storms. The introduction of wireless smart sensor networks has promise of transforming bridge management; however, their potential has been restricted by static application software that is unable to respond to changing monitoring conditions.  Under this CAREER program, a cyberinfrastructure enabled dynamically reconfigurable smart sensor framework will be created based on mobile agents. These are the software programs that traverse the wireless sensor network and act intelligently to facilitate network and sensor functionality in response to changes in the bridge loading and response.  To realize the full benefits of the bridge monitoring framework, there should be a link between the data it produces and effective bridge management decisions.  This link will be pursued by coupling extreme event data with advanced bridge response and windstorm phenomena simulation tools to enable the development of accurate coastal bridge reliability models.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project resulted in a bridge-mounted sensor system capable of autonomously collecting wave and surge loading on bridges during coastal storm events.  The development of the sensor system involved the design and integration of low-power sensor and network hardware, robust and reliable data transport strategies, and real-time data visualization methods.  The system was designed to be rapidly deployed ahead of storm events and hardened to withstand the harsh environment of storm generated wind and waves. A system prototype was developed and validated in a wave flume to demonstrate that rings of pressures sensors installed on bridge piers can provide measurements that can be converted to accurate force time histories. System networking and data transport was developed and tested over several years at a system deployment on a fishing pier near the Sunshine Skyway Bridge in Florida. The final solar-powered system was deployed on the Matanzas Inlet Bridge in Florida and successfully measured data for four months, including the passage (~100 miles offshore) of Hurricane/Tropical Storm Isaias. 

This project also supported the development of continuous wave radar for water level and wave monitoring. These low-cost, compact radar sensors are well suited to measuring water level for both infrastructure and coastal environmental monitoring. In particular, the use of these radars for measuring beach runup was demonstrated in several field tests and showed a high level of flexibility for capturing accurate, spatially distributed wave runup measurements. The bridge-mounted sensor system and the radar sensor techniques and technologies developed in this project have already impacted two additional research projects to monitor surge and wave conditions, demonstrating their applicability to support ongoing coastal infrastructure research.

In addition to sensor system development, this project also developed a concept for a bridge assessment framework to provide maintenance and safety decision support for bridges subject to damage from scour.  While scour measurement sensors are commercially available, there has not been a method for determining the probability of bridge failure resulting from measured scour without conducting in-depth structural modeling and assessment. The framework developed in this project uses a probablistic approach to convert measured scour depth into a direct assessment of pier stability without the need for a structure-specific model.

This project provided research experience opportunities for two postdoctoral students, four Ph.D. students, one M.S. student, and five undergraduate students, including several students from underrepresented backgrounds in STEM (two Ph.D., one M.S., and three undergraduate). During this project, the PI and one of the postdocs developed a new graduate course in sensor technology in the Engineering School of Sustainable Infrastructure and Environment at the University of Florida (CGN 6905: Advanced Instrumentation). The course uses lecture- and laboratory-based instruction to provide students the technical knowledge and hands-on experience to perform experimental design, data collection, and data analysis for experimental research.  In addition to fundamentals of data acquisition, this course also covers topics on state-of-the-art sensing technology and structural monitoring.


Last Modified: 12/22/2021
Modified by: Jennifer A Bridge
